Comment: I am being charged a "tariff surcharge" by every vendor at work. Right now it is generally a flat 25% increase across the board because they have no idea what is going to happen tomorrow. Personally, I appreciate that they are very transparent about the reason for the price increase so that I can transparently pass that cost on to our customers. Once people realize that this is hurting them financially they will start paying attention.   The irony about the whole thing is that just yesterday I read about how tax increases for millionaires would be a huge detriment to small businesses. Yet, forcing small businesses to price themselves out of the market in order to make a profit is a huge benefit. Someone please make it make sense.

Comment: Leavitt doesn't even understand what Inflation is: It's the comparative increase in prices from the previous year to now (or month to month, depending). Prices on Amazon went up, *which leads to inflation going up, too* - inflation is *the result* of prices rising. Tariffs are literally a tax *added on top of prices as they are*, deliberately, by the government. You cannot separate inflation from product prices, because it's an averaged market measurement, but you *can* clearly state what taxes, be they VAT or tariffs, will have to be paid on top of raw prizes. They're separate positions on the bill.

Comment: I work for an apparel manufacturer and this is how we are going to manage tariffs. Keeping the tariff as a separate line item on the invoices to our dealers allows us to keep wholesale and MSRPs the same and also be able to pivot quickly when tariffs are changed. The dealers then have a choice to pass the extra cost to customers or not - as a result the end customers will see exactly why the product is more expensive. It‚Äôs a great solution in many ways to the psychotic mess.

The initial 10% for Fent> [https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/imposing-duties-to-address-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/imposing-duties-to-address-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/)   The increase from 10% to 20% for Fent> [https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/further-amendment-to-duties-addressing-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/further-amendment-to-duties-addressing-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/)  The additional 125% "reciprocal" tariff> [https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/04/modifying-reciprocal-tariff-rates-to-reflect-trading-partner-retaliation-and-alignment/](https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/04/modifying-reciprocal-tariff-rates-to-reflect-trading-partner-retaliation-and-alignment/)   If those official .gov first party sources aren't good enough proof for you, here's a third party confirmation> [https://www.tradecomplianceresourcehub.com/2025/04/24/trump-2-0-tariff-tracker/](https://www.tradecomplianceresourcehub.com/2025/04/24/trump-2-0-tariff-tracker/)

Comment: As I said, retailers will not benefit from this. Tesla likely won‚Äôt because while they use a lot of domestic sources, a significant portion of their supply chain still comes from foreign sources. Domestic beer and liquor should see gains too. Mining will definitely boom. Energy. Defense. Semiconductors were already being pushed to manufacture in the US under Biden so they‚Äôll just continue on that path. Lots of winners, but the losers will be retailers and regular folks like us.

Comment: Let's go through the math problem as laid out in the article. I'll make up the starting tariff rate to simplify the math.  A tariff of 10% has a tariff cost of $10 for every $100 you import. If your tariff costs increase by 145% (as laid out in the article), your new tariff cost for that $100 of imports is the original tariff cost plus the cost increase. $10 plus $14.50 (145% of $10) for a new tariff cost of $24.50.   Now this is based just on the info in the article, since this administration seems to issue new EOs every hour to rescind or modify its own policies. It's impossible to keep current, by design.
